title: High Cards vs Draws
description: Master the art of choosing between high cards and drawing hands.

sections.title: High Cards in Jacks or Better
sections.content:
In Jacks or Better, high cards (J, Q, K, A) are valuable because pairing them creates a paying hand. When you have no made hand, high cards are often your best option.

But sometimes you have competing draws. Should you keep high cards or go for a flush/straight draw?

sections.title: The Hierarchy
sections.content:
General ranking from best to worst when you don't have a made hand:

1. 4-to-Royal
2. 4-to-Flush
3. 4-to-Open-Ended Straight
4. High Pair (J, Q, K, A)
5. 3-to-Royal
6. 4-to-Inside Straight (3+ high cards)
7. Low Pair
8. 3-to-Flush with 2 high cards
9. 2 suited high cards
10. Single high card

sections.title: 4-Flush Beats High Cards
sections.content: You have a 4-flush and two high cards. Which do you hold?

exampleHand.explanation: Hold the 4-flush (2h-5h-9h-Kh). A 4-flush draw has about a 1-in-5 chance of hitting, which beats holding K-Q unsuited.

sections.title: Low Pair vs 4-Flush
sections.content: You have a low pair and a 4-flush. What's the play?

exampleHand.explanation: Hold the 4-flush. A 4-flush beats a low pair because the flush has better EV. Break the pair of 4s.

sections.title: Remember
sections.content: A 4-flush always beats a low pair. But a HIGH pair (J, Q, K, A) beats a 4-flush. Know the difference!

sections.title: High Pair vs 4-Flush
sections.content: Now you have a HIGH pair and a 4-flush. Different situation!

exampleHand.explanation: Hold the pair of Jacks. A high pair beats a 4-flush because it already pays 1 coin and can improve to trips, full house, or quads.
Hold the 3-to-royal (K-Q-J suited). A 3-to-royal beats holding just two high cards because of the royal flush potential.

sections.title: Open-Ended Straight Draw
sections.content: Should you hold an open-ended straight or high cards?

exampleHand.explanation: Hold the open-ended straight (5-6-7-8). You can catch either a 4 or 9 to complete the straight. Better than holding just the Ace.

sections.title: Inside vs Open-Ended
sections.content:
An open-ended straight draw (like 5-6-7-8) has 8 outs.
An inside straight draw (like 5-6-8-9) has only 4 outs.

This makes open-ended draws much more valuable. Inside straights are usually only worth holding if they contain 3+ high cards.

sections.title: Inside Straight with High Cards
sections.content: Is this inside straight worth holding?

exampleHand.explanation: Hold T-J-Q-K. This inside straight has 4 high cards. Even if you miss the Ace, you might pair up for Jacks or Better.

sections.title: Quick Reference
sections.content:
• 4-flush beats low pair, loses to high pair
• 3-royal beats 2 high cards
• Open-ended straight beats single high card
• Inside straight needs 3+ high cards to be worth holding

practiceHands.explanation: Hold the 4-flush. It beats holding just J-Q.
Hold the Kings. A high pair beats a 4-flush.
Hold the 4-flush. Low pair loses to a 4-flush draw.
Hold the open-ended straight draw. Better than the lone King.
Hold A-K-Q. Three high cards give you multiple chances to pair up.
Hold 9-T-J-Q. This inside straight has 3 high cards.
Hold the 4-flush. Beats the single Ace.
Hold A-K. Two unsuited high cards beat discarding everything.
